CatDescriptText: Mr. William Prude, laborer, Fifth Ward and Mr. Jesse Easley, steel worker, Beltzhoover, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, March 18, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think Negroes in Pittsburgh are as progressive as those in other metropolitan cities like New Your, Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland, San Francisco, and Los Angeles? Why?"  Mr. Prude's answer reads: "No, I don't.  All they think about is something going on...Negroes here have little in jobs and power..."  Mr. Easley's answer reads: "I think they are.  They might not have as much in opportunity, but they take advantage of it."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of William Prude wearing thin moustache and light colored overcoat, standing in front of house, street no. 2715; Portrait of Jesse Easley wearing dark fedora and tweed overcoat, standing in front of Insulbrick house
